docs.lead_paragraph: THE Reagan Administration is forging ahead with its plan for random drug tests of Federal employees even as another judge ruled it unconstitutional for the Government to test people who were not suspected of using drugs. The testing program has come to overshadow other elements of President Reagan's extensive program to achieve a ''drug-free Federal workplace.'' Some conservatives in the Government, as well as many civil libertarians, have called it overly intrusive. But the Administration's strong commitment to testing reflects the depth of its concern about drug abuse. Mr. Reagan and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d ''have been driven to the point of outrage by liberal indifference to drug abuse,'' said a Presidential appointee who heads a medium-size agency.

headline.main: TESTING PLAN INDICATES REAGAN'S 'OUTRAGE' OVER DRUG ABUSE
